titleStmt.title: M1-8, 5 of 10. The Reader. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 17-20. 4p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8-5. The Reader. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 17-20. 16p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: At what point is the reader born?- this faculty, the power to make visible out of print ho men, countries, houses, & visble cou places & houses & the words & warm bodies, & their thoughts, is rare; it is not exercised on the [strips] of newspaper. It is non existent in great masses of literate the literate. It is different from the scholars gift or the critics. So then the plays are It is [illeg.] complex not in itself; for it has to see, it has to hear, but also it is for ever it is influenced at the mercy of the time circumstances always its [dupe?] One generation brings out this perceives this in the printed page; another sees that the the in the early plays, obviously, the reader becomes is scarcely in existence. We see are in the among the audence. The And that is one of the attractions of the early plays–– to be unaware of the that they bring out the spectator: make an appeal to the body: are so visible, palpable, audible. So crude: They have the frailty of They need to be read in company. They are the product of the company. If we So At their best they have the rush & the tumult of The body is always palpable in them. The humour is at some point the

But The modern reader has to read just himself But the reader is also possessed of aware another sense, besides the the power some one who connects. But, to the modern reader, there is much that is disguised of the presence of the body on the stage. This An embodiment And But at some point there comes a break. The playwright t There is a point when the playwright h has

absorbed what the audience can give him; & has consimed it; & [expresses?] his own views [about?] the audience. There is a point when the single figure emerges; as if after [absorbing?] all that the audience cd (could) [entertain?] the audience became if separate, & could [impure?] give back to the audience their general contribution specialised. And yet it was one of the immense advantages of the E (Elizabethan) age, the entire there was no gap between the giver two. It is The author There is a moment when the audience sees itself: given back; separate; created, & is no longer the master of the playwright yet is not separate from him: a kind of common life still connects them
It is then that we begin to air the read: then that we bring into play the all our whole new resources: then when the figure on the stage is able at last to g express speak in person: when the words are individual; & the whole fabric is
& yet the particular figute is the particular figure This is Their This extraordinary intensification comes fitfully: we note a passage that seems it flits through ; it is in the . Their It is in in words like : oh God... or in the & of course finally in the [metal?] is final: we have heat, light, everywhere. But besides this Beyond The reader then extracts out an [hunger?]: for their intensity; for their language. But beyond this there is also the relation of part to part. This hanging comport order, is often attracted. The balance is important. The draw of the audience is too

too powerful, in play after play: it creates improvisation; crowd; confusion; a sense of waste; here profane; here bareness. The The character is volubly explored; & in the wings propituous bound to the wheel of the plot. And apparently the lack of curtains makes the anonymous player is [irreparable?] in the wrong [same?]. He bolts his words out; has no [existence?]; deforms. We are left in the end with out But an end. And so much of the emotion is wasted.

p.s: All this of course leads up to the
It is thus, in [ready?] [illeg.] through a handful of the

div.p: If, however, we scramble the plays together, taking them as a not so much as separate creations, but as a we can unite them not separately, but as a great complete experiment: as the common effort to sede explore in their immense [reserves?] of emotion; an an expression which in becomes at last finalised; when all its it has been then has been freed, that [shocked?], when the as a repeated experiment, which relieves its [pressure?] at last, until Sh (Shakespeare) succeeds. Only It Its silence The [workshop? woodshop] is without laws. There is no comment. We are left thus to read fitfully; [unsatisfied?]: without direction. Unless indeed we see the bodily cauldron of their plays; & conceive that the nameless, uncommonly [illeg.], were somehow all compressing to [thread?] [illeg.], towards And the or the we & the were also ressign their weight their

longing for release from silence... so that at last the met scraps [found?] & the weight & the heat, & the heavy pressure of the present formed under his hands into that the expressiveness wh. is still says more than has ever been said since.

p.s: But how much is due ot the stage, how much to the audience, how much to silence itself And
